title: Chillán
text:
Chillán () is the capital <a href="List%20of%20cities%20in%20Chile">city</a> of the <a href="%C3%91uble%20Region">Ñuble Region</a> in the <a href="Diguill%C3%ADn%20Province">Diguillín Province</a> of <a href="Chile">Chile</a> located about south of the country's capital, <a href="Santiago">Santiago</a>, near the geographical center of the country. It is the capital of the new <a href="%C3%91uble%20Region">Ñuble Region</a> since 6 September 2015. Within the city are a railway station, an <a href="Coach%20%28bus%29">inter-city bus</a> terminal, an agricultural extension of the <a href="University%20of%20Concepci%C3%B3n">University of Concepción</a>, and a regimental military base. The city includes a modern-style enclosed shopping mall in addition to the multi-block open-air street market where fruits, vegetables, crafts and clothing are sold. The nearby mountains are a popular destination for skiing and <a href="hot%20spring">hot spring</a> bathing.
Founded by the Spanish in 1580 the city insisted despite numerous attacks by <a href="Mapuche">Mapuche</a>, <a href="Pehuenche">Pehuenche</a>s and other tribes <a href="Arauco%20War">in war with Spain</a>. Over time Chillán became an important marketplace where Mapuches, Pehuenches, <a href="Mestizo">Mestizo</a>s and <a href="Criollo%20people">Criollos</a> met. Many goods from <a href="Patagonia">Patagonia</a> and the <a href="Pampas">Argentine Pampas</a> were brought into the market of Chillán across the mountain passes of the area. In the early 19th century the countryside of Chillán was ravaged by the <a href="Chilean%20War%20of%20Independence">Chilean War of Independence</a> and a subsequent <a href="banditry%20in%20Chile">banditry epidemic</a>. In 1939 the city was devastated by <a href="1939%20Chill%C3%A1n%20earthquake">a large earthquake</a> prompting the government to initiate an extensive reconstruction program.
History.
The zone where Chillán was built was previously inhabited by indigenous people called "Chiquillanes".
Chillán was founded in 1580 at the site of <a href="Chill%C3%A1n%20Viejo">Chillán Viejo</a> as San Bartolomé de Chillán by <a href="Mart%C3%ADn%20Ruiz%20de%20Gamboa">Martín Ruiz de Gamboa</a>,
who was campaigning against the local indigenous peoples at the time, but this moniker did not fare well, and was replaced by the current name, which in the local Indian language means "where the Sun is sitting".
During the <a href="Mapuche%20uprising%20of%201655">Mapuche uprising of 1655</a>, the city was besieged by Mapuche warriors. The Spanish defended the city from trenches and a palisade fort. Hoping for a miracle, the Spaniards put an image of Mary near the trenches, against which Mapuches are said to have shot arrows. In early March, about one month after the onset of uprising, distress was such that the Spaniards abandoned the city and headed north, escaping the conflict zone. The <a href="Real%20Audiencia%20of%20Santiago">Real Audiencia of Santiago</a> declared the evacuation an act of cowardice, and prohibited refugees from Chillán to go beyond the <a href="Maule%20River">Maule River</a> north. As an outbreak of <a href="smallpox">smallpox</a> occurred among the refugees, this was. in effect. a quarantine, as trespassing north was punished with death sentences.
From its foundation, Chillán has been at the heart of Chile's rich agricultural region. It is also in a region of seismic activity, suffering from devastating earthquakes throughout its history; the <a href="1939%20Chill%C3%A1n%20earthquake">1939 Chillán earthquake</a> left over 30,000 dead and mobilized international help.
Chile's <a href="List%20of%20national%20founders">founding father</a>, <a href="Bernardo%20O%27Higgins">Bernardo O'Higgins</a>, was born in Chillán in 1778. He was the force behind <a href="Chilean%20War%20of%20Independence">Chile's Independence</a> from <a href="Spain">Spain</a>, being elected <a href="President%20of%20Chile">supreme director</a> and declaring independence after the <a href="Battle%20of%20Chacabuco">Battle of Chacabuco</a> against the Spaniards in 1817. His later victory at the <a href="Battle%20of%20Maip%C3%BA">Maipo</a> battlefield cemented the country's freedom. He died in exile in <a href="Peru">Peru</a> in 1842.
Climate.
Chillán has a <a href="Mediterranean%20climate%23Warm-summer%20Mediterranean%20climate">Mediterranean climate</a> (<a href="K%C3%B6ppen%20climate%20classification">Köppen climate classification</a> "Csb"). Winters are cool but mild, with a July average of . Most of the precipitation falls during this time of the year, with May to July being the wettest months, averaging over . Summers, though, are dry and warm, with a January average of , and during this time, precipitation is rare, averaging only 2–3 days per month from December to February. Temperatures can occasionally exceed from October to April. The average annual precipitation is , but it is highly variable from year to year, with 1982 being the wettest year at and 1998 being the driest year at only .
The air in Chillán is the fourth-most polluted in Chile, after <a href="Santiago">Santiago</a>, <a href="Temuco">Temuco</a>, and <a href="Concepci%C3%B3n%2C%20Chile">Concepción</a>. "As in Temuco, the main cause of air pollution in Chillán is the use of wood-burning stoves; about 62% of all households in Chillán use firewood as their main source of heating."
Demographics.
According to the 2002 <a href="census">census</a> by the <a href="National%20Statistics%20Institute%20%28Chile%29">National Statistics Institute</a>, the commune of Chillán spans an area of and has 161,953 inhabitants (77,007 men and 84,946 women). Of these, 148,015 (91.4%) lived in <a href="urban%20area">urban area</a>s and 13,938 (8.6%) in <a href="rural%20area">rural area</a>s. The population grew by 8.3% (12,442 persons) between the 1992 and 2002 censuses.
The <a href="demonym">demonym</a> for a person from Chillán, used for more than 400 years by local residents, is "Chillanejo", yet this is not found in the Royal Spanish Academy Dictionary, which only recognizes "Chillanense".
Notable people.
In addition, Chillán has offered a number of artists. A notable example is <a href="Claudio%20Arrau">Claudio Arrau</a>, a <a href="pianist">pianist</a>. Additionally, <a href="Ram%C3%B3n%20Vinay">Ramón Vinay</a> is the tenor who played <a href="Otello">Otello</a> in the 1950s, his recording of the role with Toscanini. He was a regular at the New York City <a href="Metropolitan%20Opera">Metropolitan Opera</a>, where he sang both tenor and baritone roles. One of his last performances at this house was as the <a href="Barber%20of%20Seville">Barber of Seville</a>'s Basilio, a bass role. He retired from the stage in 1969.
Other "Chillanejos" include writer <a href="Marta%20Brunet">Marta Brunet</a>, sculptor <a href="Marta%20Colvin">Marta Colvin</a>, painter <a href="Pacheco%20Altamirano">Pacheco Altamirano</a>, and <a href="Juan%20de%20Dios%20Aldea">Juan de Dios Aldea</a>, who, however, did not reach the international acclaim achieved by Arrau and Vinay. "<a href="Super%20Smash%20Bros.">Super Smash Bros.</a>" player <a href="Gonzalo%20%26quot%3BZeRo%26quot%3B%20Barrios">Gonzalo "ZeRo" Barrios</a> who had a record-breaking 56-tournament winning streak is also from Chillán.
Administration.
As a commune, Chillán is a third-level <a href="administrative%20division%20of%20Chile">administrative division of Chile</a> administered by a <a href="municipal%20council">municipal council</a>, headed by an "<a href="alcalde">alcalde</a>", who is directly elected every four years. The 2008-2020 "alcalde" is <a href="Sergio%20Zarzar%20Andonie">Sergio Zarzar Andonie</a> (ILE).
Within the <a href="electoral%20divisions%20of%20Chile">electoral divisions of Chile</a>, Chillán is represented in the <a href="Chamber%20of%20Deputies%20of%20Chile">Chamber of Deputies</a> by Carlos Abel Jarpa (<a href="Social%20Democrat%20Radical%20Party">PRSD</a>) and Rosauro Martínez (<a href="National%20Renewal%20%28Chile%29">RN</a>) as part of the 41st electoral district, together with <a href="Coihueco">Coihueco</a>, <a href="Pinto%2C%20Chile">Pinto</a>, <a href="San%20Ignacio%2C%20Chile">San Ignacio</a>, <a href="El%20Carmen%2C%20Chile">El Carmen</a>, <a href="Pemuco">Pemuco</a>, <a href="Yungay%2C%20Chile">Yungay</a> and <a href="Chill%C3%A1n%20Viejo">Chillán Viejo</a>. The commune is represented in the <a href="Senate%20of%20Chile">Senate</a> by Victor Pérez Varela (<a href="Independent%20Democratic%20Union">UDI</a>) and <a href="Felipe%20Harboe">Felipe Harboe</a> (<a href="Party%20for%20Democracy%20%28Chile%29">PPD</a>) as part of the 13th senatorial constituency (Biobío-Coast).
Transport.
The city of Chillán is connected to Chile's capital Santiago by both a modern highway and a rebuilt railway system <a href="TerraSur">TerraSur</a> that makes the trip in less than five hours. TerraSur, which terminates in Chillán station, and the <a href="Alameda%20railway%20station">Alameda-Temuco train</a> both operate on the railway connecting Chillan with <a href="Rancagua">Rancagua</a> and <a href="Santiago">Santiago</a>.
